oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Trenton Rosenwald School: gym entrance
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of the gymnasium entrance at Trenton Rosenwald School.

Constructed in 1928, the Trenton Rosenwald School (TRS) was originally a one-story, seven-classroom school funded partially through the Rosenwald Fund. The local African American community contributed $1,500, the Rosenwald fund contributed $2,100, and the remaining $11,000 came from public sources. For over two decades TRS functioned as part of the segregated public education system that was separate but not equal. TRS offered grades 1st through 8th and served as a feeder school to the only Gibson County high school for blacks located twelve miles away in Milan. Students could pay $1.00 to $2.00 a month for bus transportation to attend high school. In early 1953, TRS was destroyed by fire. Local newspapers indicate that the officials quickly approved funding for a new seven-classroom building.
